race.name: Coast to Coast
race.tagline: Michigan ultra-distance crossing from Lake Huron to Lake Michigan.

vitals.start_time: Early morning start (204-mile requires day/night riding)
vitals.aid_stations: Multiple aid stations for ultra distance

climate.description: June conditions with potential for heat. Day/night riding for 204-mile option.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads across lower Michigan. Relatively flat to rolling terrain with moderate elevation overall.
features: State crossing (Lake Huron to Lake Michigan)

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional ultra-distance event. 204 miles is serious challenge but regional field and infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Coast to Coast offers a genuine ultra-distance challenge—204 miles crossing Michigan from Lake Huron to Lake Michigan. The 100-mile loop option provides a more accessible alternative. It's a well-organized regional ultra event with good support, but the field is regional and the terrain is relatively flat Michigan gravel. The adventure of crossing the state is the main appeal.
weaknesses: Relatively flat terrain (less challenging than mountain ultras)
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional ultra-distance gravel race with the unique appeal of crossing Michigan. The 204-mile option is a serious challenge, though the terrain is less demanding than mountain ultras. Worth it for Michigan cyclists or those seeking an ultra-distance challenge in the Midwest. Not a destination race for distant travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Regional Michigan ultra-distance crossing the state from coast to coast.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Michigan or the Midwest and want an ultra-distance challenge—yes, it's a well-organized event with unique appeal. If you're traveling from far away—there are more prestigious ultra-distance events elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better ultra-distance: Unbound XL (Kansas), Dirty Kanza (Kansas), Trans Iowa. For similar regional ultras: other Midwest ultra-distance events.

logistics.airport: Detroit (DTW) or Grand Rapids (GRR) - varies by start/finish
logistics.lodging_strategy: Au Gres (start) and Ludington (finish) have lodging. Book early. Shuttle logistics for 204-mile.
logistics.food: Stock nutrition for ultra distance. Aid stations provided.

history.origin_story: Ultra-distance gravel event crossing Michigan from Lake Huron to Lake Michigan.
history.reputation: Growing regional ultra-distance event in Michigan.

course_description.character: Relatively flat to rolling Michigan gravel crossing the state.

suffering_zones.label: First Quarter
suffering_zones.desc: 50 miles in, settling into ultra pace.

course_description.ridewithgps_name: E24 12 Michigan 2024 Coast to Coast Gravel Grinder (autotraced)

non_negotiables.why: 204 miles requires extensive endurance base and ultra-distance preparation.
204-mile option requires riding through the night with lights and navigation.
Ultra-distance success depends on conservative pacing and not going out too hard.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 204 miles crossing Michigan from Lake Huron to Lake Michigan.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional ultra-distance challenge with 100-mile loop option.

logistics.explanation: Point-to-point from Au Gres Marina at 6:00 AM to Ludington requires vehicle shuttling or crew coordination. Race organizers offer optional Breakthrough T1D crew support for those without personal support. As Jackie Gregory discovered during navigation issues in the forest sections, GPS failure combined with limited course marking can create problems when "you could barely see anything, but trees on each side of you."

length.explanation: 204 miles earns maximum respect as ultra-distance that separates endurance racers from weekend warriors. Selene Yeager learned this reality: "Experience has taught me that burning even a few matches that early in a 200+ mile day will fry you three-quarters of the way in." The distance creates proper time pressure with strategic checkpoint management at mile 166. Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: Matt Acker designed the route as "quintessential Michigan; rural country roads, farmland, dense forest, creeks, rivers, rolling hills, white pine stands, two-tracks." While forest sections include snowmobile trails and single-track, this isn't technical mountain terrain. The challenge comes from sand and navigation rather than gnarly descents or rock gardens. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Jackie Gregory noted the 100-mile version has "maybe 3,000 feet of climbing," suggesting the 204-mile route's 5,000 feet provides gentle rolling terrain. Matt Acker describes "rolling hills" through hardwoods and uplands, but this is Michigan's lower peninsula - barely noticeable undulations that won't challenge riders familiar with mountain climbing. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 81°F and lows of 59°F, with a 44% chance of rain on any given day. Matt Acker warns "weather in Michigan is largely a question mark in the spring months. We've been known to be graced with 80 degrees and sunshine but also 35 degrees and freezing rain." Sarah Porch experienced this volatility when temperatures "escalated" beyond the predicted low 80s, creating unexpected heat and humidity challenges. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Michigan's lower peninsula between two Great Lakes provides zero altitude training effect. Jackie Gregory noted it's "about 10 degrees cooler there" compared to Nebraska, but that's climate difference, not altitude. You're essentially at sea level with zero thin air challenges throughout the entire 204-mile route. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Touching your tire to Lake Huron at sunrise, then racing 204 miles to Lake Michigan creates geographic adventure most races can't match. Selene Yeager captured the journey's evolution: "Manistee National Forest is where wood fairies come from... everywhere I looked as we dove through snowmobile tracks beneath heavy canopy was crisp, green ground cover speckled with tiny white flowers."

prestige.explanation: Selene Yeager's Bicycling.com coverage of the inaugural event brought national attention with 300 starters, but the race hasn't developed significant pro field presence. The unique lake-to-lake concept provides geographic prestige, yet lacks the competitive depth or prize money that draws elite fields to headline gravel events.

race_quality.explanation: Matt Acker co-designed a thoughtful course progressing from farmland through "Manistee National Forest's winding two-tracks" with 85% dirt/gravel. However, Jackie Gregory's experience getting lost when "following tracks of other people that got lost" and volunteer confusion about cutoff times reveals organizational gaps that affect race execution.

experience.explanation: Touching your tire to Lake Huron at sunrise, then racing 204 miles to Lake Michigan creates adventure. The course evolution from grasslands through pine barrens to "majestic" forest delivers variety most races can't match. Starting at 6 AM in 57°F temps and chasing sunset to Ludington has cinematic appeal.

community.explanation: Sarah Porch highlights Midwest hospitality: "Several residents set up water and cooling stations for the racers. One kind family put up a sunshade, chairs, and a table so racers could stop and take ice and cold bottled water, or play in the sprinkler." The 300-rider inaugural field suggests strong regional participation, though competitive depth remains limited.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 100-300 riders, zero data on field size or competitive depth. No notable winners or pro participation mentioned anywhere. When your biggest endorsement comes from "Minister of Gravel," you're not drawing the sport's elite to Michigan's lower peninsula. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: 204 miles of varied Michigan terrain from Lake Huron to Lake Michigan typically delivers solid value, though no entry fee data is available. The unique two-lakes concept and crew support options add worth. Sarah Porch's experience with resident-provided aid stations suggests community value beyond race organization alone.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-150. Ludington offers lodging options as a tourist town, but you'll need transportation between Au Gres start and Ludington finish unless you're doing the 100-mile loop. Michigan isn't cheap but isn't Colorado resort pricing either. Crew requirements could add vehicle costs for some. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
